node.title: Convergence error of a simple cantilever beam dynamics simulation
node.bodyText:
I tried to use the tensor-mechanics module in moose to solve a simple beam dynamics problem, but it seems to be some convergence problems.
problem statement：
This is a 3-D cantilever beam with a fixed left boundary end and a uniform downward pressure on the upper surface. I used the Newmark time integration method to simulate this problem, here is the geometric model of the beam and my input file:

`
[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
[]
[Mesh]
  [generated_mesh]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 3
    nx = 9
    ny = 3
    nz = 3

    xmin = 0
    xmax = 10
    ymin = 0
    ymax = 1
    zmin = 0
    zmax = 1
    boundary_name_prefix = bar
  []
[]

[Modules/TensorMechanics/DynamicMaster]
  [all]
    add_variables = true
    strain = FINITE
    density = 1000
    newmark_beta = 0.25
    newmark_gamma = 0.5
    hht_alpha = 0
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [left_x]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = bar_left
    value = 0
  []
  [left_y]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
      boundary = bar_left
    value = 0
  []
  [left_z]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
      boundary = bar_left
    value = 0
  []
  [Pressure]
    [top _pre]
        boundary = bar_top
       function = 1e5      
       hht_alpha = 0
    []
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [elasticity]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = 1e9
    poissons_ratio = 0.3
  []
  [stress]
    type = ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = NEWTON
  line_search = none
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu'
  end_time = 10
  dt = 0.001
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-5
  [Predictor]
    type = SimplePredictor
    scale = 1
  []
  [./TimeIntegrator]
    type = NewmarkBeta
    inactive_tsteps = 1
  []
[]

[Outputs]
  csv = true

  checkpoint = false
  [console]
    type = Console
  []
  [exo]
    type = Exodus
    interval = 1
  []

[]

[Postprocessors]
  [point_A_disp_y]
    type = PointValue
    variable = disp_y
    point = '10 1 0'
  []
  [dt]
    type = TimestepSize
  []
  [nolinear_residual]
    type = Residual
  []
[]
`

Error note:
The computation converges normally at the beginning, but as the computation proceeds, the nonlinear residuals end up getting larger and larger, and a decrease in the time step does not solve the problem.

Few ideas,

I think you are converging on the relative residual. Let's automatically scale and make the tolerance tighter.

  nl_abs_tol = 1e-10
  automatic_scaling = true 


Look at whether the problem needs damping. Newmark will grow unstable without any damping over time.
thank you!! I will try.
thank you! It works.

node.title: Custom Diffusivity
node.bodyText:
Hi,
what would be the most straight forward approach of creating a custom diffusivity material that takes the components  k diffusion coefficients d in phase B, where the coefficients are expressed as a function of temperature and pressure?
Ideally this works as an extension within the Millington Quirk material or as a modification, where the diffusion_coefficient vector accepts other materials or aux_variables as input. Right now Millington Quirk only accepts direct input of float values.
Thank you

You'll have to write your own material to achieve this, but it shouldn't be too difficult. There are examples of taking variables and using them inside the material, eg, PorousFlowPermeabilityConstFromVar.

I tried writing my own Base, so that I could then use the custom diffusion coefficients in the other diffusivity objects.
Any hints?

files.zip

So, the diffusion coefficients can be variables, so PorousFlowDiffusivityBase can't be used? It might be better to generalise PorousFlowDiffusivityBase to accept variables, then you won't need to make your own base material and then it should be easier to implement your version of MillingtonQuirk?
Let me know and I'll help you do this as I should have picked this up in your initial question! Feel free to drop me a message and we can get this done - it should be easier than you having to repeat all of this!

Thank you, that is exactly what I wanted to do, I could have also been more precise in my question.
Initially I thought I would just do the change for the MillingtonQuirk Material - however, I then realized that it would make more sense like you just described: The diffusion coefficients should accept variables as input. In that way, they can also be temperature or pressure dependent, as desired by the user (which is also more physically accurate I think). Also this can then be used in other diffusivity materials as well.
This change would need to be in the Base Material. Ideally, this can then be pushed in a following update, so everyone can benefit from this. (Also, reiterating my request from #26788: PorousFlowThermalConductivityTensorFromVar.zip I did a similar thing for the thermal conductivity based on the PermeabilityTensorFromVar material, this could then also be done in the course of this.)
So how do we proceed from where? I am somewhat on a schedule, so it would be nice to be able to plan ahead.

Hello
If you want to use variables for these coefficients, this is not a large change and you can definitely either:

add materials that do that
add an option for choosing the variable instead of the material property
OR
use the functor APIs and be able to support both variables, functions and functor material properties. See this page
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Functors/index.html

Are you planning to contribute this to the porous flow module?
You can do all of this in your application first (that builds with the porous flow module)
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
If I manage it I would certainly like to contribute it.
I hoped the change could be as simple as changing the input_diffusion_coeff in the header and .C file to something like
... std::vector<variable_value> ... So far this did not work.
Mind you, I do not have strong coding background, so a lot of the things I am doing when digging in the code is a combination of copy & past + trial & error.

std::vector<variable_value this wont work. VariableValues MUST be references, and there are no vectors of references. So you could make a vector of pointers instead.

a lot of the things I am doing when digging in the code is a combination of copy & past + trial & error.

this is how I started too! I would follow the tutorials again for training if you want to get a little better at C++ first
maybe this extra one
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/examples_and_tutorials/tutorial01_app_development/index.html
Hey @marinsiebert - if you want I can start this off and you can finish it/ test it?

As much as i like messing with the code, any help is very much appreciated @cpgr
After @GiudGiud remark about pointers I was now (still) looking at std::vector<variable_value> with * inside the brackets, this was actually accepted by the compiler, but I am not sure how to populate this now.
OK. I'll make a start on it

Check out https://github.com/cpgr/moose/tree/pfdiffvar - the last two commits have the changes I made. This will enable you to use an AuxVariable in place of the diffusion coefficient, which I assumed is what you wanted.
So you should be able to do something like
diffusion_coeffs = 'd00 d01 d10 d11'

where d00 etc are aux variables
Works as intended. Thank you!

node.title: GMG and AMG
node.bodyText: In my research to determine the capability of MOOSE to perform Geometric Multi-Grid, it appears that the ability to apply GMG is limited. It appears the dominant method for use is AMG. Are there any developed examples in MOOSE that I can use to test GMG implementation?

hello
I think we could do some form of GMG using adaptivity steps iirc. Start with a mesh that is coarse but that we want to refine, refine a few levels, then use coarsened solves to make progress faster.
@lindsayad do you know where to look for that?
Guillaume
@GiudGiud Sounds like a great idea. Given my area of interest, it would appear too me that the lid-driven cavity flow problem would be an ideal development case.

We support grid sequencing in MOOSE, which is a loop outside of the the nonlinear solve (inside of the time stepper). You can grep for num_grids in the MOOSE repo for some demonstrations of that. However, that's clearly not GMG. We have not propagated GMG into MOOSE. The best place to read about GMG for libMesh is libMesh/libmesh#2047

node.title: Assistance Required: Issues with Calling AuxVariable in GeneralVectorPostprocessor
node.bodyText:
Dear moose experts,
I hope this message finds you well. Recently, I have been working on developing a custom VectorPostprocessor named FeatureMatePropVectorPostprocessor, which is derived through public inheritance from GeneralVectorPostprocessor. In this class, I need to access an AuxVariable, and to achieve this, I've attempted to initialize it in the constructor using the coupledValue function. However, during the compilation process, I encountered the following error:
In file included from /home/pw-moose/projects/yinglong/build/unity_src/vectorpostprocessors_Unity.C:3:
/home/pw-moose/projects/yinglong/src/vectorpostprocessors/FeatureMatePropVectorPostprocessor.C: In constructor 'FeatureMatePropVectorPostprocessor::FeatureMatePropVectorPostprocessor(const InputParameters&)':
/home/pw-moose/projects/yinglong/src/vectorpostprocessors/FeatureMatePropVectorPostprocessor.C:17:21: error: 'coupledValue' was not declared in this scope; did you mean 'coupledScalar'?
   17 |     _energy_elastic(coupledValue("energy_elastic")),
      |                     ^~~~~~~~~~~~
      |                     coupledScalar
make: *** [/home/pw-moose/projects/moose/framework/build.mk:151: /home/pw-moose/projects/yinglong/build/unity_src/vectorpostprocessors_Unity.x86_64-conda-linux-gnu.opt.lo] Error 1 
In an attempt to resolve this issue, I included the Coupleable.h header file to make the CoupledValue() function available, yet the problem persisted. Furthermore, following the compiler's suggestion, I tried using the coupledScalarValue() function. Unfortunately, this approach did not suit my needs as it failed to correctly call the AuxVariable during the simulation phase.
Given these challenges, I am seeking guidance on the correct method to call an AuxVariable within a VectorPostprocessor Object. Could you please advise on how to address this issue? Any suggestions or insights you could provide would be greatly appreciated.
Thank you for your time and assistance. I look forward to your valuable input.
Best regards,
Wei

Hello
This vector postprocessor must not inherit the Coupleable interface (a base class to MANY objects, so often that we forget it has to be inherited).
What are the base classes for this VPP? What does it inherit from?
If not from Coupleable, then add public Coupleable to the header, and add it to the constructor too
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
Thank you very much for your guidance; the previous issue has been resolved. However, I've encountered another problem. The simulation indicates that the value of the auxvariable type requiring coupling must be based on nodes rather than elements. Afterwards, I converted the auxvariable type variable into the MaterialProperty type and used getMaterialProperty to call it within the VectorValuedProblem (VVP). Surprisingly, it compiled successfully, and the simulation passed.
Therefore, I believe the issue I encountered revolves around understanding why converting the auxVariable type quantity into the MaterialProperty type quantity leads to normal simulation. This seems to involve grasping the concept of [_qp].
Best wishes,
Wei

[_qp] is indexing the property (or the variable value) at the index of the quadrature point (Qp) on the element (or side for a sideVPP).
Properties and variable values are computed for all the Qps at once when considering an element, for efficiency reasons. Then you can pick the value you need from that array of size number of Qps in the quadrature for an element (/side)

Hi Guillaume,
Thank you for your insightful guidance. Additionally, after consulting some resources, I've gained a clearer understanding of the distinction between nodes and quadrature integration points. Here's my interpretation: Nodes are points located at the physical positions of an element, instrumental in defining the element's geometric shape and interpolation functions. Consequently, field variables (such as displacement, temperature, etc.) are approximated at these nodes. On the other hand, Gauss quadrature integration points serve as internal points for numerical integration, strategically distributed within the element to facilitate the calculation of integral properties (like components of the stiffness matrix and mass matrix), thus accurately assessing the element's contribution to the overarching problem.
Moreover, my understanding extends to the definition of MaterialProperty type parameters, which seems to be inherently linked to [_qp]. This can be observed when outputting _qp in MaterialObject, which always outputs values in the range 0 to 4, when the TRI3 grid type and first-order Lagrangian shape function was used. I'm curious to know if my interpretation aligns with reality.
Finally, I'd like to delve deeper into whether it's possible to output parameters of the MaterialProperty type as nodal. Specifically, I'm referring to the possibility of outputting values for the VuxVariable elastic_energy in AuxKernel::ElasticEnergyAux using the node type, rather than the element type. To my knowledge, AuxKernel::ElasticEnergyAux primarily outputs values based on the element type. I wonder if there's a way to adjust this to node-based outputs. If it is possible, how should ElasticEnergyAux be modified? If not, what is the reason?
Best wishes,
Wei

Hello

Finally, I'd like to delve deeper into whether it's possible to output parameters of the MaterialProperty type as nodal.

there are currently no nodal material properties, due to the ambiguity of which material definition to use when the node is in between two blocks.

Specifically, I'm referring to the possibility of outputting values for the VuxVariable elastic_energy in AuxKernel::ElasticEnergyAux using the node type, rather than the element type

so with an auxiliary variable, you CAN use nodal variables. But dont rely on using material properties at nodes to that.
I think what you may want to try if you MUST have a nodal variable is:

use an elemental variable (for example a MONOMIAL variable) to convert the material property to an aux-variable
use a ProjectionAux to project this elemental variable onto a nodal variable

Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
Using ProjectionAux did not work, I used the following input settings,
[AuxVariables]
  [./f_elastic_elem]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
  [./f_elastic_node]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  [../]
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [./f_elastic_elem]
    type = ElasticEnergyAux
    variable = f_elastic_elem
    execute_on = TIMESTEP_BEGIN
  [../]
  [./f_elastic_node]
    type = ProjectionAux
    v = f_elastic_elem # Variable to take the value of.
    variable = f_elastic_node
    execute_on = TIMESTEP_END
  [../]
[]
ProjectionAux did not successfully map f_elastic_elem to f_elastic_node.
Wei
how different are they? what do they look like?
f_elastic_elem is as expected, but f_elastic_node is always 0.

Interesting. which timestep are we seeing in this picture?
I ll run a quick test locally
EDIT: elem to nodal should work.
Are you sure we are not watching the result at timestep_begin? What is the output execute_on flag?

The timestep is step 03, and the output module is executed at timestep_end.
[Outputs]
  execute_on = 'timestep_end'
  [my_exodus]
    type = Nemesis
    file_base = ./${my_filename}/out_${my_filename}
  [../]
[]
By the way, even if two auxkernels are set to run at timestep begin or end, the results will be the same as the one just uploaded.

ok weird.
This does not seem right. Is there maybe an inactive or active parameter set for auxkernels that would prevent the kernel from executing? Do you see it executing with Debug/show_execution_order=ALWAYS?
Is there a material property output or a transfer that could be overwriting the auxvariable value? or another auxkernel?
Guillaume

node.title: Pressure Boundary Condition set by MultiApp
node.bodyText: Hi, I have a THM multiapp which calculates pressure, I have transferred pressure back to the main application as an AuxVariable, I would like to set the Pressure boundary condition using the data from the AuxVariable on the sideset. What is the right way to for me to set the data in the Pressure boundary condition?

Hello

I would like to set the Pressure boundary condition using the data from the AuxVariable on the sideset

which solve is this boundary condition for? A multiD flow solver or another THM one?
Or is this litteraly Pressure from the Pressure action for solid mechanics?
Guillaume
I couldn't have been more vague could I? Its the solid mechanics pressure, https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/bcs/Pressure.html

ok Pressure only takes Real and Functions. @bwspenc @somu15 do you know which BC does pressure with auxvariables?
I m wondering if we just use this one but they will know
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/bcs/CoupledVarNeumannBC.html

not sure. Can you play with the environment flags to include /usr/bin/gcc at link time?
if that does not work we ll ask Roy where libmesh looks

@jessecarterMOOSE I managed to solve that by declaring the following variable before running the ./update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh :
export CPPFLAGS=-I/path/to/your/libtirpc/installation/

node.title: Is it possible to apply AllenCahn kernel to vector variables?
node.bodyText: I am developing a new phase field model. It requires the evolution of an ordered vector parameter with 12 components. Each component of this vector obeys the Allen-Cahn equation. Using 12 coupled variables in the input file can do this, but it is super inconvenient. Is there any other way to do this?

Hello
If the equations are very similar, then you can use array variables for this. One variable with 12 components.
@laagesen do we have those for AC?
Guillaume

Hi @RWTHLHK - We normally use Actions to automate adding multiple variables and kernels for multiple Allen-Cahn equations. Have a look for example at the page https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/phase_field/Grain_Growth_Model.html and in particular the section Simplified MOOSE Syntax and pages linked there. You may be able to use what is already there or modify those actions for your specific model.

node.title: How to determine scaling
node.bodyText:
Hi，
I saw the Convergence criteria in the porous flow module, but I still don't understand how to determine scaling. Can someone give an example of determining scaling?
Thank you for your help.

Hello
You determine scaling usually by looking at the equation residuals. See the option in the Debug block
Is automatic_scaling , a parameter to set in the executioner, not working for you?
Guillaume
When I use automatic_scaling, the computed results become very small. What could be the reason for this?

hello
scaling should not affect the results. It should affect the size of the residuals, especially when comparing between variables.
Which variables do you have?
Without scaling, what does this show?
[Debug]
  show_var_residual_norms = true

With automatic scaling, what does it show?
Did you read this page?
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/source/systems/NonlinearSystemBase.html#scaling
Guillaume
This problem has been solved, thank you very much for your answer.
